topic.title: Code Editor (w/run)
topic.body:
Following in the footsteps of nullpo. (Nullpaste)

There's a new frontend with split screen editors (left is code/run) (right is load/save) and will add a fork function as i find time. (the buttons in red box still reload page, so save first until there's a better page state handler)  Adding our own scripts to the dropdown examples is next on the list.

It's primarily for javascript/canvas dev and code sharing.
Please add your own suggestions. Thanks.

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1NFUSEDZjmCFJE1JSG5UjwCRK6zDwQRQd7

topic.title: Ethereum Studio Trial (free until 15-May)
topic.body:
Ethereum Studio is a tool for decentralized application development, and includes;
- Ethereum in a Sandbox - try it for real before you deploy.
- Solidity - the language of decentralization.
- Unit test - constantly test your projects functionality
- One click deploy - deploy your project anyway in one click.
- Web UI - develop any complexity UI for you D-App.
- Web 3.0 debug - set break point ,stop, and easy fix the bug.

https://live.ether.camp/

topic.title: Ethics of site cloning and code reversing.
topic.body:
Might as well use my last few Kbs..
.
All three of my projects use code from other zites. I did not ask permission, but i DO mention or link to those projects in-app. (in the case of FlappyBird it was already a straight port to ZN)
.
This will happen a LOT on ZN since;
- cloning is commonplace (a function of ZN)
- it's easy on ZN (designed into ZN)
- we're a hacker type userbase ("off-grid" anon users)
- zite owners will disappear (limited site storage quota stops users from contributing)
- everything on ZN is open-source (unless a zite owner puts in time obfuscating or encrypting code)
- bitcoin addresses (zites might actually make money... someday)
- ...
.
The only resolution i came to is to use vanity urls and make them long enough (ie. unique enough) not to allow phishing type clone attacks. It's inevitable that someone will clone a site and compete with an owner, so obfuscating is one solution, but it takes time and skill. One's best defense is to have an active community who is loyal to the zite creator. If you think someone outright "stole" a site, then don't use it and don't host it. Conflicts will occur, but don't be nasty or we'll have.. (drum-roll) *Zite Wars!*
.
ps. in the case of null-paste the code *was* obfuscated, but i'm a pretty skilled "reverser" and it was a learning exercise.  ;)
.
Anything i've missed?

topic.title: Electron version of Zeronet available
topic.body:
Electron allows us to do some interesting things with the browser, but it's early days so this is for ppl who are familiar with node.js and npm, and where anonymity is not critical. (work in progress)

https://github.com/kustomzone/Fuzium

This is built with the Zeronet-win (dev) version that Tamas has been working on, so thanks to him for getting that running!

topic.title: LBRYians
topic.body:
Thinking whether to integrate LBRY protocol with Fuzium. Are there any other Lbryian testers here?

If not, try this referral link.. https://lbry.io/get?r=ef4vI ..and then post your own referral link here in order to gain early access. (i'll swap this post's referral link to the next person's link once i'm invited) For more info check: https://steemit.com/cryptonews/@press-release/lbry-beta-goes-live ..or the FAQ: https://lbry.io/faq

topic.title: Staying Zeronet
topic.body: I've tried Zeronet, and prolly some other with a cutesy name which wasn't so good, and to be honest i found Zeronet to be suited to coders like myself. There's just so few bugs to worry about. Unlike my own programs, this thing rarely ever crashes. I can see at least 1% of the internet using this someday cos it's so darn easy. Over the last 20 years i've been collecting a LOT of scripts and waiting for a decentralized project to let my creativity loose without worrying about centralized control, hosting fees or renewing domains, and Zeronet seems to have achieved all this. So while other p2p projects also interest me, i'm staying on Zeronet, with a message of thanks to the hard work of the creators for making these projects for coders like me. Whoever can handle the less-than-perfect shite i'm likely to produce are welcome to click clone, or heck, just copy the folder and give it your own vanity address, the more the merrier. And i'm certainly going to be here cloning or on github forking and hacking every Zeronet related zite i can find, that's for sure. I'm not going anywhere. Who's with me? Hi.

There was a lot of angst on reddit over the possible bitcoin fork and censorship thereof.
Along with their tipping platform they're well acquainted with these concepts.
Also the popularity of ZN beyond traditional western influence should be viewed as a positive
for similar reasons. Data suggests China mines the most bitcoin, despite crackdowns on it's use.
It's unclear whether the GFoC will target these technologies directly, but we'll find out
sooner than later by the looks of it. Exciting times.

1_1Ja2gA7t3Kc2CLL5GgVGr7pJTmTxdVygmS.body:
You sometimes have to reload the all.js file in the browser to update your changes. Leave a second browser tab open with it listed on screen, then when you make changes to other files, you then re-sign the site, then reload all.js, then your changes will work on the site.

On windows you can make a .bat file which saves you having to copy and paste the private key etc. So you would have "zeronet.py --debug siteSign  [site hash]  [private key]" in a myfile.bat and run it by double-clicking. The all.js is only updated (compiled) in --debug mode.

Guessing this excludes /data  .db & .json files?  (ex. zeromail.db)

ah, locally rebuilt from json. that makes sense.

- is there a way to handle multiple .db files per site?  (ie. separate dbs)

Although we've coined the word 'Zites' ...we should also think 'Zapps'.
ZeroBundle could be packaged with single platforms in mind, with an app folder ready to go.
Webkit is too large, but there should be a smaller wrapper that works just fine.
No need to worry about peers, as the Zapps would have already been published in the usual way.
@nofish has previously mentioned one solution.. (April '15)
"Posibilities: use py2exe and pack everything to an exe (like electrum)"

9_1DcDDitsjFJohvwonPmpibRChmA7uGxqL7.body:
The minimum you can withdraw is 100000000 Satoshi. (1 BTC)
That's 10,000 x 10,000. :P
How long from when you started?

Well, at say $2.50 USD a day and about 6 months effort.. IF they pay.. that would be pretty good return for someone in a poor country with cheap power. So yeah.. all hinges on the "IF.."

Though, setting the bar so high to get a payout (6 months) does make it seem like they could shut up shop just before having to make the first payouts, and walk away with 100% ad revenue for the cost of a cheap domain.

I'm just saying that the idea of faucets is to give small amounts to lots of people.. not $450 to someone who puts months into it. Obviously they want lots of people to start trying and give up. Obviously they want tons of referral hits. So again, it's a great business strategy, but it's not what faucets are really about. Good luck thou!

54_1GtJqyJRsuZhmxVtw5USgvqGbUmVH7EmBD.body:
Can link to other zites, but can't load content in a cross-domain way.
Any file reference to localhost is blocked as a security measure.
I still like the idea of having lots of content spread on multiple zites, 
so apart from having a very light interface and jumping between zites, 
not sure if there's another way.

That would be a clever way to implement it. Resigning site assets would break static links, but that would also work as a deterrence for leeching of bandwith. (the content.json is public so it would require outside crawlers to scan for any changes) The zite owner would likewise need to manage these "virtual" links from the central site, but Zeronet could introduce multi-site signing at some stage.

Speaking of crawlers (phantomjs or similar) would that be a way around the issue of cross-domain? (possibly using dynamic resigning and live-publishing of assests, ex. only as or when they are being requested)

14_15ATNsS6aHGvBg5xoMP94sXpNaLX4fSHjN.body:
In data.json find title of 'P2P news flow' you'll see "type": "group",
add it your own data.json & sign it

The root content.json normally has "ignore": "data/.*", so it doesn't sign data/user files.
We can do that manually -> zeronet.py siteSign [siteaddress] --inner_path data/users/content.json
But prolly @nofish did it on ZeroTalk, otherwise we do it on our cloned forum as owner.

6_13hcYDp4XW3GQo4LMtmPf8qUZLZcxFSmVw.body:
He's only been back from holiday about 5 days and working on social app, and has to go to Berlin. Let him finish the app.

http://127.0.0.1:43110/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit/

It is clear to anyone that @nofish is not an anonymous figure like "satoshi nakamoto" was to bitcoin.
He uses his real name and does presentations and interviews to promote Zeronet.
His design is slick and friendly. His apps are collaborative and clonable. His code is open source. His use of bitcoin addresses implies web-commerce.  He is one person, answering questions on ZN, Reddit, Github, and elsewhere.

While he has done his best to make people's data safe and their identity secure, his goal looks to be openness and sharing (social, not secretive) and that is why many of us are here contributing where we can.
There are no moderators here, and everything is volunteer. It is what it is, but we can make it better by our own effort. If he wasn't so busy he would have read and answered your question by now, but he's working on something that many of us have been looking forward to using for months, so out of respect we are being patient and answering questions that he would have otherwise. That's why i'm writing this.

If you are a coder and have ideas about securing identities or communication then implement them in your own app. Or if you feel ZN is not attending to some feature you need, you are free to fork or download the source on github and run with it. There is already an alternative implementation available there. (search phantom)

Sure, point taken. fwiw, he takes donations on certain feature requests, so to a certain extent he is fulfilling existing pledges to make things like the social feature that was most in demand. Perhaps he could start a donation for decentralized IDs to gauge the demand for it also.
Yes, i've been researching that myself for a couple of months. Are you also coder?

@tk6znreaerujvrfk

1_17Cs2auSHSVjKaYMXqbNMApRQrgXcwJUpL.body:
There's also a lot of doubled (duplicated) data. 
Each data.json gets stored in SQL DB. ZeroToDo skips the DB, just using json.
I've made a DB editor to try doing it the other way. (SQL, w/o JSON) I took Zite Index json which is 360kb and put it into DB which is only 215kb. So saving is about 30%, plus the original json. (see Load -> zites_2016.db)

127.0.0.1:43110/1SQEEKkYzZuwo7X37EcET5wP6B3yAJZYo

So typically only 1 DB per zite, but DB editor might allow to bypass this, and DB size is not counted with 1MB file limit. ;)

Agree, but that's about 4 separate issues. 
- Popular users who add good content get more allotment (reputation)
- Decentralised ID which can still limit abuse. (quota)
- Site ownership. (multiple or shared private keys, or opensource DAO)
- Abuse. (see above)
We should try to solve the first issue, while planning for the other 3.
Atm, if the site owner is bad, people can easily clone the site and compete. (reputation)

> [zynklap](#comment_11_1DZr3dWHcLESuHx7UeC23QSXfQFvBdFT9s): But that would be some boring ass work, I doubt that lots of people would do it.

It's literally just changing a public key in a few places. A minute tops.

11_1KdnTJVBGzEZrJppFZtzfG9chukuMv8xSb.body:
@kickasstorents  Certainly no accusation on my part. You've been more than decent here. Sharing what you're working on, explaining in detail, and asking others to help out with a roadmap in place. Keep doing what you're doing!

I actually posted this in defense of myself as much as others. It's hard to strike the right balance, and among new colleagues we hardly know. This is all volunteer for us on an experimental platform. Time is always a factor with expenses and such. But it's good that we developers explain ourselves for non-developers, because there's sometimes the impression that we should be more diligent in how we make our apps, especially in the areas of design and attribution. There's quite high expectations that apps will be complete, polished, bug-tested, more in line with commercial software. It's not really like that here. A good layout with an 'about' page, some instructions, and friendly UI customization can take days or weeks. I'm only just at the stage of cannibalizing my previous apps as a time saving measure. It gets easier eventually, and i'm sure the quality of ZN's sites will improve, but it's largely on the "shoulders" of those who went before us, and thanking them is the least we can (and should) do.

2_1FwTZnDZJjs2epEtq9yLy7m2P5kZ4TYqAR.body: Sure, there's quite a few ways to approach this. The easiest way is with a plugin. (check your ZN plugin folder for examples) Of course people have to download the plugin to gain access, then you'd have a basic login using zeroID or custom ID of your own making which is not hard to do. In my case i've got a (very basic) alt-coin running and mining so i'm working on a suitable scheme for the ledger, but well known ones like Hyperledger (see github) have authentication built in, so that would allow users to tag content with different access levels. Hyperledger uses docker and IBM's Bluemix service, so i mention it just for the schema, which is not power hungry like Bitcoin blockchain.

7_16w7UuJAHbt8YBa8zxHS7UFk9mq8Q5DpE4.body:
Been following bitcoin/altcoins a few years. Not investing or mining, just researching. Bitcoin mining has moved into the hands of a few major players. Ethereum has taken it a step towards being not simply about wasting electricity with on-chain scripting, but it's still early days, with the recent fork being the result of design bug in the DAO payments code. Our best hope is to develop our own coin for very niche markets such as ZN where there are currently no other options for transactions between direct peers.

The cryptography and learning involved is beyond the scope of many coders so there's also the chance to shine on someone's radar which might hook into an online job here and there doing designer blockchains for bitcoin or cash. It's still an exciting field with huge potential, and here in ZTalk we can read about the many success stories in the P2P topic. The trick is to move away from Proof of Work which wastes power to another type of proof which has profit incentive built in. In the case of solar it's about running blockchains to manage the micro-grid generation in a distributed way. In the case of ZN we already have a growing pool of users who are in the habit of leaving some machine on hosting zites, so if we can biggy-back off that and help pay people's power at the same time then it's win-win and more people will join.

I've got an example miner working as ZN plugin, so just now trying to hook it up with frontend and sqlite. Should have something running soon.

> [planteater]

The word 'Work' is capitalized because it's a singular effort at wasting (throwing away) computing power and electricity. We're running a P2P network here which technically is doing the same thing so it would still be work, but have a positive outcome.. ie. the support and hosting of ZN zites.. so i'd call it Proof of (hosting, peering, popularity, bounty, etc) or a combination of those if possible.

@planteater Some of ..it quickly went off on tangents. 

i don't think it's semantics to say that the 'work' could be designed to benefit average PC/Laptop users who are keen to use their machines in a distributed way. That's how Bitcoin started, but the centralization of mining is a huge issue which has not been addressed even as the block rewards have fallen to 12.5 BTC. (~$7,500) Many alt-coins are evolving quickly to solve the problem, so i expect we'll see some challengers to Bitcoin's lead sooner or later.

26_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nwkTkKv.body:
I joined a year ago just after the ZeroHello upgrade with it's default apps skillfully made by nofish.
Although 0list was also listed it was heavily spammed and mostly unusable for zite discovery.
Then there are search engines once people can find those.

But every time we (or anyone) starts 0net we see the same default apps atop our zite list. (besides any favorites we might have) This is not a failing of nofish to create a set of uniform zites for people to get started, but for people who stay here there are issues with this design.

For example, the working proxy sites with their long lists on ZeroHello are a good gateway, perhaps better than a static list since we can see popularity and know what is alive and updated. But 0lists a like hitting "I feel lucky" on Google. We end up with many crappy random half-loaded zites with few or no peers, and then have to go through our ZeroHello deleting the mess again. So for me the homepage is the bottleneck. Perhaps this is also what kai0 means by "no images on the homepage".

Long story short, i've always thought that the default homepage should be an open app store for everyone. But besides asking everyone to edit their config file to change the homepage there was no real way forward, whether i could make a good store or not.

Then a couple of months ago i started an Fuzium (Electron) version of Zeronet, and found installer packaging allows me to set the homepage, saving people having to edit config files! So i've made a basic app store for Fuzium, and it seems to be working okay, and also works as a standalone zite, but without bookmarking manager and other Fuzium features. I'm just adding delete and rating options, but the basic store layout can be seen here;

http://localhost:43110/1LANDERvVWbShpNWpsrbBvfqSK1PabXtwv

{TLDR: still a work in progress}

https://github.com/kustomzone/Fuzium/blob/master/gfx/fuzium-screeny2.jpg

kai0: nice site, I checked your new site.

Cheers, i run it on different port (43210) so i may have hard-coded that. Not sure.
I'll make a new installer on github tonight just in case.

> you have ability to improve the site zerotalk with image.
> it's easy for you to improve this site
> http://127.0.0.1:43110/1C2JhCunGLtvyX56nQ88tcb87WnXspjWN/
> img need to dispaly on home page.

Yeah, i use basically same code for the app images, but was thinking you meant ZeroHello homepage.
Just got image auto-resizing going today which also helps as don't really want huge (NSFW) images on the homepage anyway.

> [kai0](#comment_36_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nwkTkKv): thank you! I am waiting for you to improve it。

layout is not perfect, but working. (ps. altering an existing DB is tricky, so i hacked an existing table)

http://localhost:43110/1NCRELKZ3zWRS6DijziYrfWi9dsUY8Fh8n

> [throw111](#comment_4_16i7xjhfhpmn47f249gqDYono6roEWXwhr): Really awesome! Reminds of early Yahoo - in a good way, exactly what zeronet needs :)Now it is just not working right, as when clicking a link, it changes port to 43210 (hardcoded), which doesnt work?

Thanks!

Yes, i'm running ZN on a different port in Fuzium, but people may not be using that. It's the same problem i mentioned below about changing the homepage (editing config) which is quite easy to do but, but asking people to do that seems complicated. It would be nice if we could change our homepage or port in the default sidebar, but that's something that nofish will have to decide.

There are easy solutions like cloning the site and changing the port back again, but i'm throwing Zerotalk back in there right now.. (see kai0 topics) so it's very pre-release at this stage. I've updated Fuzium (installer) yesterday and it's a goal of getting people to switch to that, but it's only on windoze atm.

https://github.com/kustomzone/Fuzium/releases/tag/v0.0.7-pre-alpha

By "goal" i mean i want to make the switch compelling enough by improving certain aspects of ZN. Ultimately it's easier to add a port or homepage option to Fuzium myself than trying to get it added to the original, so changing the port and homepage is a way of forging a new path. (ie. there are numerous reasons behind this decision)

Not hard to combine but my time is short. 

I start to understand what you are saying about cultural difference of social site design. And of course it's quite hard to design with multicultural users in mind. CMS would need more than theme of color and language options, but whole layout and such.

With your previous comment about collaboration, yes it helps. When i first started i borrowed code from nullpo (nullpaste) but he left just as i arrived. Since then main zite developer have been few (except nofish/zerome) but having more zites like just posted allows us to merge layout and start thinking about admin features for true CMS. The main collaboration so far has been code sharing (cloning) rather than joint effort on single projects. That will surely happen as zites get busier and more complex.

Also curious and waiting to hear details of nofish's new announcement as mentioned in the dev blog, if it pertains (has relevance) to any of this.

1_1MwJSNBC1savftEvXQyoHcVLDgThtAPr6T.body:
I don't think the aim is to catch the 99%. There is competition between the ones you mention to even catch 1%. If we say 5 Billion people are online by 2020, then that's still 50 Million people, which is huge.

These are all new projects so one shouldn't expect bug-free. My stuff certainly has bugs. No one is gonna pay to clone a zite i make, but a group might oneday pay a couple of bucks each to fix something that's half working. Meanwhile i'll keep making something better. More in demand.

However, nofish's stuff is as bug free as i've seen. By comparison G+ right now is so full of bugs that it's almost unusable. As people have been saying, it's pretty rare to have someone who can code and design to that level without help. It's even fully backwards compatible, because i used ZeroHello code from more than a year ago for my app-store.

Even non-coders should understand the complexity involved. This is the frontier of the current web. A voyage across the ocean on sailing ships. The first spaceflight to another planet. We shouldn't expect perfection on such a journey.

The CMS is hit clone, then open the sidebar and rename the site. It couldn't be easier for a non-coder.
After that you use any text editor to change colors. If people are afraid of text editor then they shouldn't be thinking to run a site. Certainly not expecting 99% of the internet to flock to that site. Expecting other people to do every last line of perfectly functioning code, keep your security and privacy intact and so on and so forth, just so that you don't have to even open a text editor once is disingenuous.

It is not right to run around where people are working every single day and night without lives to build something completely new and turning around and saying shit is broken so you are leaving. (i haven't even seen any posts @twiggydew has made about fixing or improving anything, which would be useful feedback) This post doesn't even mention a single bug. What are "all of these bugs" you mention? Anything not working needs to be explained, or it doesn't get fixed.

People are working hard, almost without exception for nothing in return other than praise. This 'huge golden carrot' (payday) for the project which reaches some level of perfection that is not explained isn't the way to use money to support hardworking individuals. How about asking for something very specific and offering a few hundred bucks to get it done. I mean Zeronet would not be here without the support Tamas has received from people who have been doing exactly that.

> [twiggydew] ...

``` body { background-image: url("path-to/galaxy.jpg"); } ```

So Zeronet fails because ^this^ is missing?
If only i had your research skillz! :(

Fixed.

> I wanna give a shoutout for all the tech-illiterate people who still come and use ZeroNet anyway. You guys are the real MVPs. I know I personally work hard to make my sites as user-friendly as possible to welcome people who might have issues with this stuff. But they gotta meet me half way.

Exactly. I added avatars to ZeroPlus, but the guy i was doing it for left the site a mess of requests. Of course he was asking for moderator functions, but i'm not going to make all those functions just to clean up after doing a solid two weeks work for free.

This topic is the same. A big pile of shit right in ZeroTalk. And people will complain if we censored the stupidity.
I only coded the avatars in a day (which works perfectly for me ;) as proof that these are not major issues. Paying rent is a major issue. Oh, but people want us to make a PERFECT decentalized internet first.. then they might "cough up" some money. Like.. yeah sure. How exactly does one sit, code, and not pay rent? Hmm.

> [kaffie](#comment_284_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Ideally, once I'm done with things, paying rent won't be an issue for anyone.

I read some personal issues (Kaffiene Search is opensource) might stop your coding. Not prying. I just automatically assume money is the main thing that limits people coding. (besides motivation, which is tied to money insidiously in our current society) But yes, the existing model (Googles, Facebooks, Twitter especially right now) are bad for lots of reasons which are well known.

This month we've seen Mastodon take off like a rocket. There are over 500 repos on github. By comparison Zeronet could be said to be failing. While Mastodon is mostly a Twitter clone, it's likely to evolve given this momentum. So i'm on board with the idea that Zeronet and other decentralized projects each have their own role to play in a mesh type construct of intercommunication. (a new web)

Being the biggest and killing all others is what this person really probably looking for.. One Ring to Rule Them All.
That's how the old internet works. Expecting this new web to work the same is like expecting Bitcoin to work like paper money.

15_13Z7XxTa7JuFat3KzzMWu3onwM6biLuurJ.body:
My study has mostly been in the node.js direction. Within Electron we can cross-feed data wherever there is a security roadblock in default Zeronet. The discussion and announcement of removing ajax and other techniques of reading or writing data made my decision to fork as best i could. Also my Python is still weak, compared to JS which i've used extensively. Eventually there will be a pure JS version of Zeronet, and by (eventually) swapping out some Python functions from within Fuzium is my own way of approaching that goal. The limited GO version is also a good base to work from if able to be transpiled.

Given time my python will improve, so i will look into django and a couple of other python projects that would make suitable plugins. eg. https://github.com/ReinProject/python-rein

> [throw22](#comment_1_1CLr2dxaDtxCeGVDqUZXXrWDzgNwyoXMYB): You use a fork of zeronet to do Fuzium, which is based on Electron framework, which is based on chromium, which is based on Google Chrome? ...Nevertheless please continue your work on Fuzium, maybe some people here or elsewhere figure things out because of importance with more and more people using electron as a base.

Yes, spot on!

A good number of people are on ZN for Tor, privacy, anonymity.
And a fair number are here for the de-corporatization and de-govt (US) "monopoly" control.
And yet others are here for the easy sharing of free uncensored content and self-hosting.

My own focus is on empowerment (bitcoin, gig economy), opensource, more cultural sharing (my circles on G+ are too "western centric"), and growth of userbase, connectivity, communication, collaboration, and increased usefulness in the geeky sense. And of all these things, privacy (for me at least) is at a lower priority than decentralized popularity in general.

It's been hard to make this clear, but my KB here was increased so i'm finally able to explain better.

Btw, here's another project to watch: https://github.com/lbryio/lbry

Starting with one that is over 99% PHP (grav core) is a very hard way of going about it i think.
(i done php for a few years, so i think it's not easy to just swipe the frontend part)
I've been finding some nice json-based stores that are much closer to the Zeroframe API target.

http://brian.io/lawnchair/

> [p2p](#comment_289_13Z7XxTa7JuFat3KzzMWu3onwM6biLuurJ): but I don't see lawnchair has any user experience if my tor browser renders it well.

What i mean is >99% means PHP is rendering that frontend, so to untie the frontend would a harder task. 

Decoupled frontend and backend would be preferable. But also because Zeroframe exports json, so if start by looking for json storage then it can feed a frontend (and vice-versa) then we are closer to a usable framework. 
Also with any Node.js if that is able to be used ('require') on the frontend as in Electron.

> [ooo7](spam)

Spamming a dev topic is just asking for censorship.

> [darvy]

I wouldn't give up. I've followed all your links and downloaded many more to find the shortest possible solution. People (one more notable for his 'offer' of a large reward) have asked for a various different things: Moderator functions, layout dragging, customizability, as well as member profiles. (we don't even have sigs yet! ;)

There's a few devs working on various parts. The ZeroMe modders have started a github group as a dev hangout. I wasn't sure if you were a coder, but you've been a helpful researcher and tester nonetheless. It's all progress.

> [twiggydew](#comment_6_1MwJSNBC1savftEvXQyoHcVLDgThtAPr6T): Bot just doesn't understand that ZeroNet does have a great potential to do that.

I'm a cybernaut. Done nothing but research the web for 22 years while not working. Been coding on Zeronet 12 of the past 15 months. (spent the other 3 months learning Electron and blockchains etc) Everyone saw me spend 2 weeks building ZeroPlus for Kai0 who i've never met and wasn't paying me, also while i'm not working and paying rent, so it's out of my pocket. In fact i essentially borrowed $10k during 2016 to learn what i have. Don't start this "coders don't care" shit. Your feedback is terrible. How hard is it to give simple feedback which would get something fixed instead of this "I'm leaving Zeronet" or "Zeronet has failed" attitude?

> [darvy](#comment_47_1EqerKajfi14bzTkqwSfqVrxKmQW1w6Nzk): You coders should put yourself in a non-coders place. How would you feel if you couldn't do anything to your blog because it lacks features you normally use. I haven't done one thing to my blog since I cloned it a year ago. Again I appreciate what you coders are doing but please try to add features to the blog so non-coders don't have to worry about getting into the CSS file or any of the other files. Thank you bot.

Why did i spend 2 weeks helping Kai0?

- he was clearly Chinese speaking English. People ignored him. That shouldn't happen. 
- he was persistent but not demanding.
- he asked for "images on the homepage", but i thought he meant on ZeroHello as he was suggesting it to nofish.
- when i understood what he meant i saw the simple logic of it.
- i made thumbnails (coder saving space, smaller data) ..he said no, full size.
- i fixed it, and kept fixing everything he said until it worked.
- he kept asking for moderator functions. We can't have mods without profiles, and profiles start with avatars.
- he asked for that, so i added it. Then he asked for moderator functions.

My court-ordered 2 weeks to leave my flat was up. I had told him my time was limited. I've spent the past month living in my vehicle with power cable that stops working every 2 hours, then i have to wait 1 hour for it to work again.
I'll post this before it cuts out. Winter is coming.

footnote: He cloned the site. Had some problems but worked thru them with my last posts. Started asking how to change the banner and move a button. He worked it out. He changed the background, and moved things around. His site now looks nothing like ZeroPlus. He was a non-coder. Didn't know how to change a color in css. He gained confidence and learned how to theme his own site.
He was thankful. It worked out good for both of us.

> [darvy](#comment_48_1EqerKajfi14bzTkqwSfqVrxKmQW1w6Nzk): But some of us don't want to mess with any of those files like the CSS.

And i understand that too. I guess i put the time to help someone who strongly supports Zeronet (Kai0 is very active to get more Chinese using it) also was prepared to learn. When people clone his zite, he'll likely take the time to explain it if they have the time to learn ..and so on.

So there's two approaches. Mine is to increase the number of non-coders into coders who might have patience to teach another person. We also do this by carefully labeling our css and commenting our code.
This doesn't help someone who will never look at code (they wouldn't even see our effort), but it will help those that do. This "sensei" (tutoring) way is more natural for me.

If things work out i might be able to integrate GrapeJS or similar.  Just that i've been asked to do another task to help new users of Zeronet, and i kinda doubt nofish will have time either. As i said, your research does help, and i'm thankful for that. You are also persistent but not demanding so i want to do it. 
A lot of coders have come and gone. It's concerning, thou the reasons are not so clear yet.

Devs can't work on restricted KB so ZT is not suited.

> [dun] I suppose I need to build that somehow from the coffee files

Yes, when you siteSign in ```--debug``` mode (only in debug mode) it compiles all .coffee and .js files into all.js
For testing you'll have to right-click reload frame then reload page to get the new all.js version loaded.
Another way is to increment the name like 'all-1.js' and same for index.html to load it.
If you suspect it's not reloading then that's a good way to make certain.

> [p2p](#comment_292_13Z7XxTa7JuFat3KzzMWu3onwM6biLuurJ): Then clone a ZT?

Yes, i meant this original one. Cloning ZT and boosting the user space is trivial, but people will gravitate to the most popular sites, so overcoming the "inertia" of staying on this original version of ZT is what we're working on.

> [dun](#comment_14_14nCEDo97Cx4VpSHwPytWvacPo29Y7FAbk): I am not sure what you mean by "siteSign" - is there documentation I can read, or something more about --debug mode? I have the ZeroNet and ZeroTalk repos both in separate locations - I don't really understand how they are connected, as far as builds and the js goes.

Basic use is ```zeronet.py --debug siteSign [address] [private key]``` which on Windows i save as a .bat text file and then 'run' in the main zeronet folder which has ```data``` folder containing all zites. The confusion starts with each zite having a data folder of their own for user files. So you as you move up and down your file tree it's easy to mistake one for the other.

It's somewhat worse in Fuzium atm as python is wrapped in, so sometimes uses ```data``` folder within ```core```. Until i figure it out i make data folders on a few levels and let it decide which one it wants to use.

The main tutorial is on ZeroBlog..

http://localhost:43110/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post:99:ZeroChat+tutorial+new

There is also a usability issue with ZeroHello as the first Zeronet experience, with only 0list as a next step to finding any more zites. The default homepage needed to become a 0list type page but more in the style of an appstore with easy identification of categories (indexed) so people can go straight to what interests them, and to be open for contributions from anyone (like a normal appstore) ...An 'appcentre' was needed..

13_1KdnTJVBGzEZrJppFZtzfG9chukuMv8xSb.body:
Pretty much the same question on Reddit.. "So you can share Files, pics, data, even stream movies for free or [alt-coins]. And it will get a simple user interface so that it gets mainstream. It like a newer version of torrents?"

Piggybacking some additional content by blockchain on Zeronet seems worthwhile. I know the founder of Bittorrent launched his own version of CDN for movies and it didn't take off, but this could be useful for new zites if the same files are able to be shared for users of either platform.

This is also the idea (if not the actual framework?) behind Kim Dotcom's proposed relaunch of Mega/MegaUpload.
